Name: NATHANIEL WOODS
story:
Nathaniel Woods, 44, was convicted of capital murder for the shooting deaths of police officers Carlos Owen, Harley A. Chisholm III, and Charles R. Bennett in Birmingham, Alabama. He also was convicted of attempting to murder Officer Michael Collins. 
The officers were shot while trying to serve a misdemeanor arrest warrant on Woods at an apartment in Birmingham's Ensley neighborhood on June 17, 2004. It was the deadliest day in the city police department’s history.

Name: CHRISTOPHER LEE PRICE
story:
Christopher Price was convicted for the 1991 robbery and killing of Bill Lynn, a minister in Bazemore, Alabama.
Court records state Lynn was wrapping presents for his grandchildren three days before Christmas when his power went out. He walked outside to check the power box when he was attacked. Suffering stab wounds, Lynn died en route to a local hospital.

Name: MICHAEL BRANDON SAMRA
story:
Michael Brandon Samra was convicted of capital murder and was sentenced to death for his role in the 1997 killings of Randy Duke, his fiancée, Dedra Mims Hunt, and her two daughters, 6-year-old Chelisa Nicole Hunt and 7-year-old Chelsea Marie Hunt. Randy Duke was the father of Samra's friend and co-defendant, 16-year-old Mark Duke.
The adults were shot to death, but court records state Mark Duke and Samra, then 19, slit the girls' throats with kitchen knives after they ran out of bullets.

Name: DOMINEQUE RAY
story:
Domineque Ray was sent to death row in 1999 after being convicted of murdering 15-year-old Tiffany Harville during the course of a rape and a robbery. Tiffany and her mother lived in Selma, Alabama, and her mother left home one night for a work event. When she returned home the next day, no one had seen Tiffany, and the teen’s mother reported her missing.
According to court records, Ray came to the Harville home and offered to help Tiffany’s mom search for the teen and pass out fliers. The search for Tiffany’s body lasted for months, until Marcus D. Owden came forward and told police that he and Ray were involved in Tiffany’s killing.

Name: WALTER LEROY MOODY, JR.
story:
Walter Leroy Moody, Jr., 83, the oldest inmate on Alabama's death row, is set to die by lethal injection for a bombing nearly three decades ago that killed a federal appeals court judge.
U.S. 11th Circuit Judge Robert Vance, Sr., was killed on Dec. 16, 1989 in the blast from a pipe bomb hidden in a package sent to his Mountain Brook, Ala., home. The judge’s wife, Helen, was seriously injured in the blast.

Name: MICHAEL WAYNE EGGERS
story:
Michael Wayne Eggers was convicted of intentional murder in the death of Bennie Francis Murray in Talladega, Ala.
In late 2000, Eggers came looking for a job from the 67-year-old Murray, his former employer who ran a travelling carnival concessions business. She did not hire him, but offered to give him a ride and to help him find work elsewhere. After driving him around, she took him to a remote area where he said he had left his car after accidentally driving it off the road.

Name: ROBERT BRYANT MELSON
story:
Robert Bryant Melson has been on Alabama's Death Row since 1996 after being convicted of shooting three people to death during a robbery of a fast-food restaurant in Gadsden, Ala.
Tamika Collins, 18; Nathaniel Baker, 17; and Darrell Collier, 23, all of Gadsden, were employees at Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken. They were found dead in the restaurant's walk-in freezer on the night of April 16, 1994. Another teenage employee, Bryant Archer, was shot four times but managed to escape and call police.

Name: THOMAS DOUGLAS ARTHUR
story:
Thomas "Tommy" Arthur, 75, was first convicted of capital murder in 1983 in the contract killing of Troy Wicker of Muscle Shoals, Ala. Wicker's wife had claimed she hired Arthur, who at the time was serving at a Decatur work release center for a conviction in the 1977 murder of his sister-in-law in Marion County.
Arthur has been on death row since March 1983, making him the third longest serving inmate on Alabama's Death Row. He's also the second oldest inmate there.

Name: RONALD BERT SMITH, JR.
story:
Ronald Smith was convicted in the November 1994 killing of Circle C convenience store clerk Casey Wilson during a robbery in Madison County, Ala.
Smith was charged, along with two others, with capital murder in Wilson's death. One of his co-defendants, Chad Roundtree, received a reduced charge in exchange for his testimony in the case and was sentenced to 20 years in prison. The other, Jay Allen Zuercher, was sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole.

Name: CHRISTOPHER EUGENE BROOKS
story:
Christopher Eugene Brooks was convicted in 1993 of murder during the course of a rape, robbery, and burglary for killing 23-year-old Jo Deann Campbell. A jury recommended Brooks receive the death penalty, and a judge sentenced him to death.
When he was sentenced, Brooks bellowed at the victim's family that it "ain't over yet" before storming into the prisoners' passageway leading to the Jefferson County Jail.

Name: KENNETH WILLIAMS
story:
In 1999, Kenneth Williams was less than a month into a life sentence — for the murder of University of Arkansas student Dominique Hurd the year before — when he hid in a garbage truck that was leaving a prison in Grady, Ark. He snuck into the home of 57-year-old Cecil Boren, who had been the warden at the prison years earlier and was retired. 
Williams shot Boren and took his pickup truck. He was captured in Missouri after a traffic accident, in which a delivery driver named Michael Greenwood was killed.

Name: MARCEL WAYNE WILLIAMS
story:
Early one morning in 1994, 22-year-old Stacy Errickson was abducted by Marcel Williams from a gas station in Jacksonville, Ark., near Little Rock. He forced her to withdraw money from multiple ATM machines. Nine days later, he was arrested on an outstanding warrant for a separate crime, and he confessed to the kidnapping but said Errickson was still alive. Her body was later found buried in a shallow grave. 
He was sentenced to death in 1997. On appeal, Williams’s defenders found that his trial lawyers had failed to discover that their client had suffered from abuse throughout his life. As a child and into his teenage years, he was pimped out by his mother in exchange for food and lodging. She also beat him with extension cords she had boiled. He was gang-raped while serving time in an adult prison.

Name: JACK HAROLD JONES, JR.
story:
Jack Jones was sentenced to death in 1996 for the rape and murder of Mary Phillips, a 34-year-old bookkeeper in the small town of Bald Knob, Ark., an hour’s drive from Little Rock.
Lacy Phillips, the victim’s 9-year-old daughter, testified at trial that a man who matched Jones’s description had entered the accounting business where her mother worked, forced the two of them to lie down, and took cash from a register. She said that he choked her until she passed out and hit her with a gun. She woke up as police were investigating the crime scene, where her mother had been found, strangled and bludgeoned. Using the girl’s description of the suspect, police found Jones, and he confessed to the murder.

Name: LEDELL LEE
story:
Even among death penalty cases, which are known for their complexity, the case of Ledell Lee stands out. He was sentenced to death for the 1993 fatal bludgeoning of 26-year-old Debra Reese, having previously been convicted of two separate rapes in the Jacksonville, Ark., area. He was later accused of the strangulation murder of 22-year-old Christine Lewis in 1989, but a jury deadlocked, and prosecutors decided not to retry him after his death sentence for Reese’s murder.
In the lead-up to trial, Lee argued that his attorneys had a conflict of interest, because they had been appointed to defend him in other cases and might need to use defense strategies that would work at cross purposes. Lee sued his own lawyers in order to strengthen this conflict of interest claim, but Judge Chris Piazza (who earlier in his career prosecuted some of the men up for execution this month) ruled there was no conflict of interest. A jury deadlocked 11-1 on whether Lee was guilty of Reese’s murder, but it was later discovered that the holdout juror had been represented by one of Lee’s attorneys.

Name: DUSTIN JOHN HIGGS
story:
In January 1996, Dustin Higgs participated in the kidnapping and murder of three woman: Tamika Black, Mishann Chinn and Tanji Jackson. According to federal prosecutors, after Jackson rebuffed a sexual advance from Higgs at his Maryland apartment, he and two friends offered the women a ride home. They instead drove them to the Patuxent National Wildlife Refuge. Prosecutors say around 4 a.m., Higgs ordered his friend Willis Haynes to shoot the women—and “make sure they’re all dead.” Haynes killed all three women, who ranged between the ages of 19 and 23.
Prosecutors learned that Higgs had threatened other women with a handgun and participated in one drive-by shooting. The case could be tried in federal court because the crime took place on federal land, and jurors technically gave Higgs nine death sentences. “It won't bring our children back, but we are relieved that justice was served,” Krishana Chinn, the mother of one victim, told a reporter after the trial. Higgs was the first person from Maryland to be sentenced to death in federal court. Tamika Black’s mother, Joyce Gaston, agreed: “He ordered my daughter's death, and I think it's only appropriate that his death is ordered.”

Name: COREY JOHNSON
story:
An intellectually disabled man who caught COVID-19 while on death row is one of the last in a spree of executions scheduled during the waning days of the Trump administration.
Former Virginia gang member Corey Johnson was originally sentenced to die for seven murders in the early 1990s. At the time, he and his associates—Richard Tipton and James Roane, Jr.—were running a large-scale drug ring, trafficking in wholesale quantities of powder cocaine from New York City then cooking it into crack for their network of several dozen street dealers to sell.

Name: ALFRED BOURGEOIS
story:
Alfred Bourgeois was sentenced to death in 2004 for the murder of his 2-year-old daughter. Since then, the legal battle over whether he can be executed has turned on the extent of his intellectual disability. Congress and the Supreme Court have both forbidden the execution of someone with such a disability, but state and federal courts have continually debated how precisely to determine whether someone has one.
Bourgeois was a long-haul truck driver, originally from Louisiana. In 2002, a paternity test showed that he was the father of a toddler. Bourgeois made arrangements with the girl’s mother to take her on his trucking route for a summer. According to prosecutors, over the course of a month Bourgeois punched, whipped and burned his daughter, forcing her to sit for hours on a toilet training chair. While he was delivering goods along with his wife at the Corpus Christi Naval Air Station, she tipped over the chair, and he slammed her head into the truck’s window and dashboard. A medical examiner said in court that her cause of death was “an impact to the head resulting in a devastating brain injury,” but that she had already suffered from numerous other injuries.

Name: BRANDON BERNARD
story:
Brandon Bernard is scheduled to be executed more than two decades after the double murder that sent him to federal death row, even though he did not pull the trigger.
Bernard was charged in connection with the slayings of Todd and Stacie Bagley, two youth ministers who were carjacked, abducted and shot to death in 1999 at the Ft. Hood military reservation in central Texas. A group of gang members got a ride from Todd Bagley—then pointed a gun at his head and forced him and Stacie into the trunk of their own car. After hours of driving around town trying to rob the couple, the ringleader—Christopher Vialva—shot the couple, killing Todd and knocking Stacie unconscious. Then Bernard lit the car on fire.

Name: ORLANDO HALL
story:
Orlando Cordia Hall was sentenced to die in 1995 for the murder and rape of a 16-year-old girl who he and four accomplices beat and buried alive over a $4,700 drug debt.
According to his lawyers, his life since then has been a story of redemption, just as his legal case has highlighted some of the most troubling racial disparities of the nation’s harshest punishment.

Name: CHRISTOPHER ANDRE VIALVA
story:
Christopher Vialva was sentenced to death for the 1999 murders of Todd and Stacie Bagley, two youth ministers from Iowa who were visiting Texas.
Stacie Bagley’s stepsister Dana Ladd told the Killeen Daily Herald that the victims were “a perfect couple, very loving people toward everyone.” They had stopped to use a payphone when a group of teenagers asked them for a ride; Vialva, age 19, was the oldest. According to FBI agent Daniel Chadwick, who investigated the case, their bodies were discovered in a burning car, near a lake inside Fort Hood, an Army base in central Texas.

Name: WILLIAM EMMETT LECROY
story:
William LeCroy was sentenced to death for raping and killing 30-year-old Joann Tiesler at her home in Gilmer County, Georgia, a rural area north of Atlanta in 2001.
LeCroy had already served time in federal and state prisons for the sexual assault of a child, among other convictions. He was out on probation, when, according to federal prosecutors, he made a plan to flee the U.S. He entered Tiesler’s cabin and strangled and stabbed her, and then took her car. He was arrested while trying to cross into Canada. In June 2003, while awaiting trial, he tried and failed to escape from the Lumpkin County Detention Center, according to an indictment.

Name: KEITH DWAYNE NELSON
story:
In October 1999, 10-year-old Pamela Butler was rollerblading near her home in Kansas City, Kansas, when a man grabbed her and threw her into his truck. Several witnesses described the truck to police. According to court records, police found the truck the next day, abandoned on the Missouri side of the state line, and learned from witnesses that it had been driven recently by Keith Nelson.
When police found Nelson, hiding under a bridge, he swam into a river to get away. Once he was detained, an onlooker shouted, “Where is the little girl?” Nelson responded, "I know where she's at, but I'm not saying right now."

Name: LEZMOND MITCHELL
story:
In 2003, Lezmond Mitchell was found guilty of carjacking and murder for stabbing Alyce Slim, a Navajo woman, and her 9-year-old granddaughter on Navajo land in Arizona.
Despite the gruesome nature of the crimes, the Navajo Nation, a federal prosecutor and even members of the victims’ family said they did not want the U.S. government to pursue the death penalty. But the Justice Department had other plans.

Name: DUSTIN LEE HONKEN
story:
Dustin Honken was sentenced to death in 2005, along with his girlfriend Angela Johnson, after the couple was found guilty of murdering five people in Iowa more than a decade earlier.
Honken had begun manufacturing methamphetamine in the early 1990s in Arizona. According to court records, he relied on two men, Greg Nicholson and Terry DeGeus, to sell the product in Iowa. Federal investigators found meth at Nicholson’s house, and he agreed to help them build a case against his supplier. In recordings obtained by prosecutors, Honken said he was worried that DeGeus would join Nicholson in testifying against him, and that he enjoyed killing people.

Name: WESLEY IRA PURKEY
story:
One morning in 1998, 16-year-old Jennifer Long skipped out on classes at her Kansas City, Missouri, high school and disappeared. Police initially thought she had run away, but her family did not believe this explanation.
Months later, Wesley Purkey was arrested for the murder of 80-year-old Mary Ruth Bales in Kansas. He admitted to investigators that he had also raped and murdered Long. He said he kidnapped the teenager and took her across the state line to Kansas, which meant the crime could be tried by federal prosecutors. He said that he had dismembered Long’s remains and burned them, which was why she was never found.

Name: DANIEL LEWIS LEE
story:
Daniel Lewis Lee was convicted of the 1996 killings of William and Nancy Mueller, along with Nancy's 8-year-old daughter, Sarah Powell.
Lee was a member of a white supremacist organization called the Aryan People's Republic and followed its leader, Chevie Kehoe. The Muellers lived in the Ozark mountains in northwest Arkansas, where William Mueller sold guns and ammunition, along with anti-government videos. According to court records, Kehoe and his associates had robbed Mueller once before, and this time they waited until the family returned home and killed them.

Name: ROBERT JOE LONG
story:
In the early 1980s, Robert "Bobby" Joe Long confessed to murdering eight women in Florida after being arrested in the kidnapping of a 17-year-old girl.
Police had been searching for answers after bodies were found in wooded areas and near rural roads in the area around Tampa Bay. In November 1984, Long was arrested after teenager Lisa McVey escaped from him and was able to help officers apprehend him.

Name: JOSE ANTONIO JIMENEZ
story:
In October 1992, Jose Antonio Jimenez beat and stabbed a 63-year-old woman to death in her North Miami home.
Neighbors heard the victim, Phyllis Minas, cry, "Oh God! Oh my God!" during the attack, according to court records. She was still alive when rescue workers arrived soon after.

Name: ERIC SCOTT BRANCH
story:
Eric Scott Branch was sentenced to death after being convicted of strangling and raping University of West Florida student Susan Morris in 1993.
Gov. Rick Scott signed his death warrant on Jan. 19, 2018. According to a release from Scott's office, Branch also raped and beat a 14-year-old girl in Indiana and raped a woman in Florida 10 days before killing Morris.

Name: PATRICK HANNON
story:
Patrick Charles Hannon was sentenced to death 26 years ago after being convicted of killing two men in their North Tampa, Fla., townhome.
On Jan. 10, 1991, the men, Brandon Snider and Robert Carter, were found dead. Hannon, 26 at the time, was convicted of slashing Snider's throat and shooting Carter six times.

Name: MICHAEL RAY LAMBRIX
story:
In December 1982, Michael Ray Lambrix was serving a sentence for violating probation when he escaped from a work release detail. Six weeks later, he and his girlfriend met Aleisha Bryant and Clarence Moore Jr. outside a bar.
Lambrix and his girlfriend invited Bryant and Moore back to their trailer. Lambrix lured Moore outside, then attacked him with a tire iron, fracturing his skull. Then he kicked Bryant in the head and strangled her.

Name: MARK JAMES ASAY
story:
Mark Asay was sentenced to death in 1987 after fatally shooting two people in seperate incidents in a single night.
Early on July 18, 1987, Asay drove to downtown Jacksonville after a night of drinking. First, he shot Robert Lee Booker after a verbal confrontation, telling a friend that he had to show Booker, who was black, "who is boss."

Name: OSCAR RAY BOLIN, JR.
story:
On December 5, 1986, Oscar Ray Bolin Jr. kidnapped Teri Lynn Matthews from a post office in Land O' Lakes, Fla. She disappeared after she finished a night shift at the bank where she worked in Tampa. Her car was found with the engine still running outside the post office, and her body was discovered that day wrapped in a damp white sheet in the woods by the roadside.
Her throat had been cut, her head bludgeoned.

Name: JERRY WILLIAM CORRELL
story:
Jerry William Correll was sentenced to death on Feb. 7, 1986, after being found guilty of murdering his ex-wife, Susan Correll; their 5-year-old daughter, Tuesday; Susan's mother, Mary Lou Hines; and her sister, Marybeth Jones.
The victims were discovered in Hines' house in Orlando on the morning of July 1, 1985, all with multiple stab wounds. Bloody fingerprints and palm prints that matched Correll's were found at the crime scene, according to investigators.

Name: DONNIE CLEVELAND LANCE
story:
Donnie Cleveland Lance was sentenced to death for the killings of his ex-wife, Sabrina “Joy” Lance, and her boyfriend, Dwight “Butch” Wood in 1997.
Just before midnight on Nov. 8, 1997, Lance called his former father-in-law’s house to speak to Joy, but she wasn't there.

Name: RAY JEFFERSON CROMARTIE
story:
Ray Jefferson Cromartie was sentenced to die for the murder of Richard Slysz, a food store clerk in Thomasville, Ga., in April 1994.
The day before Slysz's death, Cromartie went to the Madison Street Deli armed with a borrowed .25-caliber and found Dan Wilson washing pans. Cromartie shot Wilson in the neck and then tried to get into the deli's register. A surveillance camera captured the sound of the shots from the back of the restaurant and an image of Cromartie trying to open the register.

Name: MARION WILSON
story:
Marion Wilson and Robert Earl Butts were 18-year-old members of the Folk Nation gang when they saw off-duty correctional officer Donovan Corey Parks in line at a Milledgeville, Georgia, Walmart.
On the night of March 28, 1996, the two were trying to fulfill a gang requirement that they commit violent acts when they saw Parks paying for cat food.

Name: SCOTTY GARNELL MORROW
story:
Four days after Christmas in 1994, Barbara Ann Young informed her ex-boyfriend Scotty Morrow over the phone they were through.
He had tried to get her to take him back, but Young stood firm.

Name: ROBERT EARL BUTTS, JR.
story:
Robert Earl Butts and his buddy, Marion Wilson, were both 18 and members of the Folk gang when they got in line behind an off-duty correctional officer at a Milledgeville, Ga., Walmart.
Donovan Corey Parks was out buying cat food on the night of March 28, 1996. Butts bought a pack of gum and followed the officer out of the store.

Name: CARLTON GARY
story:
Carlton Gary is one of Georgia's most notorious serial killers, coming to be known as the "stocking strangler" who terrorized elderly women in the late-1970s.
Gary was linked to seven murders in Columbus, Ga., and two sexual assaults that occurred over seven months in 1977 and 1978. He also was tied to the strangulations of two women in New York and attacks on others in the years before the killings in Columbus.

Name: J.W. LEDFORD
story:
Despite being just 20 years old, J.W. Ledford had been drinking and using drugs half his life when he murdered his 73-year-old neighbor Dr. Harry Johnston on Jan. 31, 1992.
According to testimony at the trial in Murray County, Ga., Antoinette Johnston had just seen her husband drive away in his pickup with someone in the passenger seat when Ledford knocked on the door and asked to speak with the physician.

Name: WILLIAM C. SALLIE
story:
William Sallie's wife, Robin, had filed for divorce in December 1989 after an argument that ended when he struck her with a belt. Robin Sallie took their 2-year-old son and moved in with her parents and siblings in nearby Bacon County, Ga. Under the pretence of visting his son, Ryan, Sallie came to his in-laws' house and took the child to Illinois, where he stayed until a court there ruled the mother could take the toddler back to Georgia.
Sallie returned to Georgia in March, 1990, and rented a mobile home near Hinesville, Ga. and had a friend buy him a handgun.

Name: STEVEN FREDERICK SPEARS
story:
Steven Frederick Spears was convicted in 2007 of murdering his ex-girlfriend six years earlier.
Spears told investigators in Lumpkin County that he had warned Sherri Holland when they started dating that "if I caught her or found out she was (with) somebody else, I'd choke her... to death." Spears also told other people he had warned Holland.

Name: GREGORY PAUL LAWLER
story:
Gregory Lawler was sentenced in 2000 to die for murdering Atlanta police officer John Sowa and critically wounding his partner, Patricia Cocciolone.
On Oct. 12, 1997, Lawler and his girlfriend, Donna Rogers, argued as they walked home from an Atlanta bar. A witness saw Lawler hit her with a bag and told the police. Minutes later, Sowa and Coccilone found Rogers, intoxicated, sitting on a curb, so they drove her to the townhouse where she lived with Lawler.

Name: JOHN WAYNE CONNER
story:
John Wayne Conner was sentenced to die for beating to death his friend, J.T. White, after the drinking buddy said he wanted to have sex with Conner's girlfriend.
Conner, Beverly Bates and the 29-year-old White had spent the evening at a party in Eastman, Ga. At the end of the party, the group returned to Conners' house and wanted to keep drinking, even though it was past midnight on Jan. 10, 1982. Conner and White then set out for a neighbor's house in hopes of getting a ride to the liquor store for more bourbon. Unable to get a ride, they walked back to the house, and White "made the statement about he would like to go to bed with my girlfriend," Conner told investigators. "So I got mad and we got into a fight."

Name: DANIEL ANTHONY LUCAS
story:
Daniel Anthony Lucas and a partner were burglarizing a Jones County, Ga., home on April 23, 1998, when they shot a father and his two children one-by-one as they came home.
Bryan Moss was the first to be killed. The 11-year-old saw Lucas, then 19, and Brandon Joseph Rhode through the front window, ransacking the house. The boy came through the back door armed with a bat, and Lucas shot him.

Name: KENNETH EARL FULTS
story:
Kenneth Fults pleaded guilty to murdering his next-door neighbor Cathy Bounds on Jan. 30, 1996 when he broke into her Spalding County, Ga., home.
Fults later told police he committed several burglaries during a week-long crime spree, because he planned to use a stolen gun to kill his former girlfriend's new boyfriend.

Name: JOSHUA BISHOP
story:
Joshua Bishop murdered Leverett Morrison because he would not give up the keys to his Jeep.
Bishop, Morrison and another man, Mark Braxley, spent several hours drinking at a Milledgeville, Ga., bar on June 24, 1994, before deciding to go to Braxley's trailer to continue their evening.

Name: TRAVIS HITTSON
story:
Travis Hittson was 21 years old in 1992 when he and another sailor visiting Houston County, Ga., murdered and dismembered a fellow shipmate from the U.S.S. Forrestal, an aircraft carrier based in Pensacola, Fla.
Petty Officer Edward Vollmer had invited Hittson and Conway Utterbeck to go with him to his parents' home in Warner Robins, Ga., for the first weekend in April in 1992.

Name: BRANDON ASTOR JONES
story:
At the time of his execution, Brandon Astor Jones was the oldest man on Georgia's Death Row, born in 1943 and sentenced to die for a 1979 murder.
Roger Tackett, the 29-year-old manager of a Tenneco convenience store, had come to the Cobb County, Ga., business just before midnight on June 16, 1979, to lock up, but he stayed around after closing to do paperwork.

Name: BRIAN KEITH TERRELL
story:
Brian Keith Terrell was sentenced to die for shooting and beating to death an elderly man, John Watson, at Watson's Newton County home on Georgia Highway 142.
Terrell's mother was a close friend of Watson's and regularly drove him to his dialysis treatments. Evidence at trial showed that days after Terrell was released from prison in 1992 after serving time for robbery and other charges, he stole 10 checks from Watson's home and began using them. When Watson discovered that his checks had been stolen and learned that Terrell's name had been signed on some of them, he informed Terrell's mother and summoned a sheriff's deputy. Watson gave a report to the deputy; however, he asked the deputy not to pursue the case yet. Watson then agreed with Terrell's mother not to press charges if Terrell returned a significant portion of the stolen money within a few days.

Name: MARCUS RAY JOHNSON
story:
Marcus Ray Johnson met Angela Sizemore at an Albany, Ga. nightclub in 1994. The next morning, March 24, 1994, a man walking his dog found her battered and bloody body in her Suburban, which was parked behind an apartment complex.
Witnesses said Sizemore was so drunk, a bartender took away her keys. Witnesses also said Sizemore and Johnson started kissing soon after they met, and then they left together. That is what first made Johnson a suspect, and soon after Sizemore was discovered, police met Johnson at a church where a friend had dropped him off. The friend was going to get money to loan Johnson so he could go to Tennessee.

Name: KELLY RENEE GISSENDANER
story:
For some time the only woman on Georgia's death row, Kelly Gissendaner was sentenced to death for orchestrating her husband's murder at the hands of her lover.
On the evening of Feb. 7, 1997, Gissendaner went to a bar with friends, leaving Gregory Owen at her home in Auburn, Ga., along with a nightstick and a knife. Owen lay in wait for Douglas Gissendaner, who was spending the evening with friends from church.

Name: WALTER BARTON
story:
Walter Barton was sentenced to death for the 1991 murder of Gladys Kuehler, the elderly manager of the southwest Missouri mobile home park where he had lived.
Barton, now 64, was convicted of the murder of Kuehler in 1994. Kuehler, who was 81 when she was killed, ran a mobile home park in Ozark, Missouri, about 20 miles from Springfield.

Name: RUSSELL BUCKLEW
story:
In 1996, Russell Bucklew went to the trailer in Cape Girardeau County, Mo., where his ex-girlfriend, Stephanie Ray, was living with her new boyfriend, Michael Sanders. Bucklew shot and killed Sanders and kidnapped and raped Ray. While driving away with Ray, Bucklew got into a gunfight with a state trooper, wounding the officer, and was himself shot before being arrested.
He was convicted on multiple crimes and sentenced to death by a jury in 1997 for Sanders' murder.

Name: MARK CHRISTESON
story:
Mark Christeson was sentenced to death for the 1998 murders of Susan Brouk, 36, her 12-year-old daughter, Adrian, and her 9-year-old son, Kyle.
According to police records and court documents, Christeson and his cousin, Jesse Carter, snuck out of the home of a relative in Maries County, Mo. on the night of Jan. 31, 1998, with the intent of stealing a Ford Bronco that belonged to Brouk, who lived nearby. They were 18 and 17 years old, respectively.

Name: EARL FORREST
story:
In December 2002, an intoxicated Earl Forrest and his girlfriend got into an argument with Harriet Smith, who had allegedly reneged on a deal in which she would give Forrest a lawn mower and a mobile home if he introduced her to a source of methamphetamine.
Forrest shot and killed Smith and a visitor, Michael Wells, before stealing a lock box that contained methamphetamine and returning home. In a shootout with police, Forrest shot and killed sheriff's deputy Sharon Barnes and wounded Sheriff Bob Wofford. Forrest himself was injured in the shootout.

Name: CAREY DEAN MOORE
story:
Carey Dean Moore was sentenced to death in 1980 for the murders of Reuel Van Ness Jr. and Maynard Helgeland, two cab-drivers in Omaha. Both were 47 years old. Moore was 22 at the time.
He has detailed the crimes in his prison writings. In August 1979, along with his 14-year-old younger brother, Moore approached Van Ness, who had stopped his car. He pointed a gun at the back of his head, demanding money. Van Ness reached for the gun, and Moore fired. He and his brother then drove off in the victim’s car.

Name: ROBERT VAN HOOK
story:
Robert Van Hook was convicted of the 1985 murder of David Self in Cincinnati.
Van Hook, 25 at the time, met 25-year-old Self in a Cincinnati gay bar, and the pair spent several hours drinking. They then went back to Self’s apartment together. There, Van Hook attacked and strangled Self until he was unconscious. He killed Self with a kitchen knife and attempted to cover his tracks by shoving the knife inside Self’s body and smearing fingerprints left behind.

Name: GARY W. OTTE
story:
Gary Otte was convicted of robbing and killing two people in 1992.
On Feb. 12, 1992, Otte talked his way into 61-year-old Robert Wasikowski's apartment in Parma, Ohio. He shot Wasikowski in the head and stole $413.

Name: RONALD PHILLIPS
story:
Ronald Phillips was sentenced to death for the rape and murder of his girlfriend's daughter.
In 1993, Phillips was 19 and living with his girlfriend, their son and her two daughters in an apartment in Akron, Ohio, above his grandparents' home. After the oldest girl, 3-year-old Sheila Marie Evans, collapsed one day and was taken to the hospital, doctors found that she had severe internal and external injuries consistent with repeated beatings and sexual abuse. She died within hours.

Name: CLAYTON LOCKETT
story:
Clayton Lockett, along with two accomplices, abducted Stephanie Neiman and three others during a home invasion in June 1999 and drove them to a remote farm road in northern Oklahoma. They shot Neiman and left the 19-year-old gasping for breath in a muddy ditch, where she died.
Lockett admitted to investigators that he killed Neiman, saying "I did shoot that bitch."

Name: CHARLES RHINES
story:
Charles Rhines was found guilty in 1993 of murdering Donnivan Schaeffer while trying to rob the Dig ‘Em Donuts in Rapid City, South Dakota, where Schaeffer worked. In the view of his defense lawyers, Rhines is facing execution because is gay. To prosecutors, he will die because he committed an especially awful murder.
According to one state lawyer’s summary, Rhines “locked Donnivan’s head between his knees and pounded a hunting knife into the base of Donnivan’s skull, partially severing his brain stem.” After robbing the store, Rhines went to eat, and when found by police he admitted to stealing roughly $1,700, and he laughed while comparing the victim to a beheaded chicken.

Name: RODNEY SCOTT BERGET
story:
Rodney Berget was sentenced to death for killing correctional officer Ronald "R.J." Johnson while attempting to escape from the South Dakota State Penitentiary in 2011.
He had been sentenced to life in prison in 2003 for a murder and kidnapping, according to court records. “I came up with a way to try to get out of the penitentiary, but I needed to get a guard's uniform,” Berget said at a hearing in which he pleaded guilty. When he saw Johnson emerge from an office, “I came as fast as I could without making any noise, and I started hitting him in the head with my pipe until he went down and he wasn't moving any longer.”

Name: NICHOLAS TODD SUTTON
story:
Nicholas Sutton, 58, was sentenced to death for the 1985 slaying of a fellow prisoner at the Morgan County Regional Correctional Facility in Morgan County, Tennessee. He had previously been sentenced to life in prison in the killing of the grandmother who raised him like a son.
His grandmother Dorothy Sutton, then 58, was reported missing by other family members on Christmas Day, 1979. Searchers found her body four days later in the Nolichucky River and an autopsy concluded she drowned in the icy waters.

Name: LEE HALL
story:
Leroy Hall Jr., 52, was sentenced to death for the 1991 slaying of Traci Crozier, his ex-girlfriend.
Now legally known as Lee Hall, he was found guilty of first-degree murder and aggravated arson by a Hamilton County jury in 1992.

Name: STEPHEN MICHAEL WEST
story:
Stephen Michael West, 56, was sentenced to death for the 1986 murders of a woman and her 15-year-old daughter in their Union County, Tennessee, home.
Wanda Romines, 51, and Sheila Romines, were both stabbed to death, their hands bound behind their backs.

Name: DONNIE EDWARD JOHNSON
story:
Donnie Edward Johnson was sentenced to death for the Dec. 8, 1984 murder of his wife, Connie Johnson, in Memphis.
He suffocated his wife by stuffing a large plastic bag down her mouth in the offices of a camping equipment center where he worked, according to court documents. Johnson then asked an inmate on work-release at the camping center to help him move Connie Johnson’s body into her van.

Name: DAVID EARL MILLER
story:
David Miller was sentenced to death for the 1981 murder of Lee Standifer, a 23-year-old woman he met in Knoxville, Tennessee. Tennessee's longest serving death row prisoner, he has been awaiting execution there for 36 years.
According to reporting by The Tennessean, Standifer was diagnosed as a child with mild brain damage and was just moving out of her parents' house and beginning work at an assembly line when she met Miller at a library. When she didn't show up for work, her parents reported her disappearance to the police, who found her body, beaten and stabbed, in the woods. Multiple witnesses had seen the Miller with Standifer. At trial, Miller's lawyers argued there was not enough proof that he killed Standifer, but the jury found him guilty and sentenced him to death.

Name: EDMUND GEORGE ZAGORSKI
story:
Edmund Zagorski was sentenced to death in 1984 for the murders of John Dale Dotson and Jimmy Porter. Prosecutors argued that Zagorski lured the two men into the woods, promising to sell them marijuana, and then shot them, slit their throats, and took their money.
Before trial, Zagorski told his lawyers that if he was found guilty he'd prefer the death penalty, and he told them not to present any evidence that might persuade the jury to spare his life. His lawyers did not travel to his hometown in Michigan or investigate his family background beyond calling his mother.

Name: BILLY RAY IRICK
story:
Billy Ray Irick was convicted in Knoxville, Tennessee in 1986 for the rape and murder of 7-year-old Paula Dyer. He had been living with her family, often taking care of the children.
One night, he called Dyer’s step-father Kenneth Jeffers and said, “I can’t wake her up.” When the Jeffers arrived, he found the child on the floor, with blood between her legs. An autopsy showed she had been asphyxiated. The next day, Irick was found hitchhiking on a highway entrance ramp. He was taken in for questioning and confessed to the murder.

Name: BILLY JOE WARDLOW
story:
In the summer of 1993, Billy Joe Wardlow shot and killed an elderly man during a botched robbery in East Texas. He was just 18, and later said he wanted to steal 82-year-old Carl Cole’s pick-up truck so he and his girlfriend could escape their abusive families.
But the hold-up did not go as planned; Cole ended up with a bullet between the eyes, and more than 25 years later, Wardlow is scheduled for execution amid a global pandemic.

Name: ABEL REVILL OCHOA
story:
When police arrested Abel Revill Ochoa, he told them he couldn’t handle the stress and had simply gotten tired of his life, so he’d gunned down his family.
The 29-year-old Dallas man cooperated with police from the start and confessed to the five murders, ultimately blaming his violent outburst on the drugs he’d smoked less than half an hour earlier.

Name: JOHN GARDNER
story:
In late 2004, Tammy Gardner marked a date on her calendar: Feb. 7, the day her divorce would become final. She’d come to fear her husband, John, and counted down the days until he would officially be out of her life.
But the divorce didn’t go through as planned. On the evening of Jan. 23, 2005, sheriff’s deputies responding to a 911 call found Tammy in her bedroom, shot in the head and bleeding heavily.

Name: TRAVIS TREVINO RUNNELS
story:
Travis Runnels was sent to death row for slitting the throat of prison worker Stanley Wiley during a 2005 outburst at the Clements Unit boot factory.
At the time, the Dallas man was roughly a decade into a 70-year sentence for aggravated robbery, and he’d grown desperate in his time behind bars.

Name: JUSTEN GRANT HALL
story:
Former gang leader Justen Hall admitted to police that he strangled Melanie Billhartz with an electrical cord, then ordered her fingers chopped off before ditching her body in the desert in 2002. The killing was part of an effort to prevent her from drawing attention to an El Paso drug house where Hall and other white nationalists made meth.
Even though no one saw the killing, Hall was sentenced to die in 2005. At first, he waived his appeals. But in 2013—more than a decade after Billhartz's death—his attorneys asked for DNA testing, arguing that Hall had falsely confessed, and forensic testing on the cord would prove his innocence.

Name: ROBERT SPARKS
story:
Just after midnight on Sept. 15, 2007, Robert Sparks put his hand over his wife's mouth, and stabbed her 18 times as she lay in bed in their Dallas County home.
Then, one at a time, he woke up his stepsons—9-year-old Harold and 10-year-old Raekwon—and stabbed them 45 times each, dragging their bodies into the living and stashing them under a comforter.

Name: MARK ANTHONY SOLIZ
story:
Mark Anthony Soliz was sent to death row for a string of violence that spanned two counties and ended with the murder of a 61-year-old North Texas woman.
In June 2010, Soliz and his buddy Jose Ramos stole long guns and a 9-millimeter semiautomatic in a burglary. For the next week, they robbed strangers at gunpoint, shot a man in the ear, killed the driver of a beer delivery truck, pulled off a carjacking, burglarized homes and shot a man repeatedly in a drive-by.

Name: BILLY JACK CRUTSINGER
story:
When police arrested Billy Crutsinger in 2003, he was drinking in a bar on Galveston Island.
Meanwhile, more than 300 miles away, a Fort Worth neighborhood was reeling from a double stabbing that rocked the community three days earlier. It was a crime to which the then-48-year-old admitted his guilt, offering up DNA samples and a taped confession when police brought him in. Five months later, he was sentenced to death. Since that time, he’s filed appeals arguing that he was actually innocent, had a bad lawyer and that the trial judge should have suppressed any evidence stemming from his arrest.

Name: LARRY RAY SWEARINGEN
story:
Larry Swearingen was sentenced to death in 2000 after he was found guilty of raping and murdering of 19-year-old college student Melissa Trotter, then dumping her body in the Sam Houston National Forest in Texas.
He has since spent almost two decades on death row as courts cancelled five execution dates.

Name: JOHN WILLIAM KING
story:
James Byrd Jr. was walking down Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard in the early morning hours of June 7, 1998 when three men in an old-model, side-step pick-up stopped to give him a ride. The 49-year-old was on his way home from a party in Jasper, Texas. It was during those cool, pre-dawn hours in the small town known as the Jewel of the Forest that one of Byrd’s friends saw him for the last time, riding in the back of the gray pick-up.
Later that day, police found Byrd in front of a black church. His pants were around his ankles, and his head was missing. It turned up more than a mile down the bucolic country road.

Name: BILLIE WAYNE COBLE
story:
Billie Wayne Coble was distraught over the failure of his third marriage when he killed his estranged wife's parents and brother in the summer of 1989.
A Vietnam veteran with no prior criminal convictions, Coble was sentenced to die the following year and has fought his case ever since. Now, he's one of the oldest prisoners on Texas's death row.

Name: ROBERT MITCHELL JENNINGS
story:
Robert Jennings had been paroled from a 30-year aggravated robbery sentence—his second—for a little more than two months when he entered a Houston adult book store on the night of July 19, 1988, intent on robbery.
When he stepped inside, however, he chanced upon Houston Police Vice Officer Elston Howard, 24, in the process of arresting store clerk Larry Overholt for a municipal licensing violation. Overholt later testified that Jennings walked up to the officer and fired twice, an account Jennings confirmed in his own statement three days after the slaying.

Name: ALVIN AVON BRAZIEL, JR.
story:
It was a fall evening in 1993, and Douglas White had gone out for an after-dinner walk with his wife, Lora.
But as they strolled along the walking trail at a Dallas-area community college, a man came out of the bushes and pulled a gun. He demanded their money, but the newlyweds had none.

Name: JOSEPH CHRISTOPHER GARCIA
story:
Joseph Garcia was sent to death row for the 2000 killing of a police officer after escaping from prison with six other men.
Garcia had been in prison for stabbing a man to death when he joined a notorious prison break-out. One of the so-called "Texas 7," Garcia and the other escapees who survived were all sentenced to die—some of them under the controversial law of parties—for the slaying of Officer Aubrey Hawkins, who in December 2000 was ambushed and gunned down outside of Dallas.

Name: ROBERT MORENO RAMOS
story:
In late March of 1992, police picked up Robert Ramos for an outstanding traffic warrant. Eight days later, he confessed to burying the bodies of his wife and two youngest children under the floor of the family’s Progreso, Texas, home.
The Mexican national was taken to trial in Hidalgo County and sent to death row the following year, where he has spent the last quarter century fighting his case based on claims of bad lawyering and international treaty violations.

Name: DANIEL CLATE ACKER
story:
Nearly two decades after the murder that landed him on death row, Daniel Acker still maintains that he didn’t do it—and that there wasn’t even a murder to begin with.
Instead, the East Texas man has claimed for years that the death of his girlfriend, Marquetta George, was an accident.

Name: TROY CLARK
story:
Troy Clark was sent to Texas' death row for torturing and drowning his ex-housemate before stuffing her body into a barrel of lime, a crime for which he’s long professed his innocence.
The 50-year-old Tyler, Texas, man was convicted of the 1998 killing of Christina Muse, a slaying intended to keep the woman from snitching on him for his dealings in drugs, according to court records.

Name: CHRISTOPHER YOUNG
story:
In 2004, Christopher Young shot and killed Hasmukhbhai Patel, an owner of a San Antonio mini-mart, during a robbery.
The slaying landed the Bexar County man on Texas' death row.

Name: DANNY PAUL BIBLE
story:
Danny Bible first killed in 1979. Four years later, he did it again. Now, nearly four decades on, Bible is aging and in a wheelchair as he faces an execution date.
The former drifter was behind a slew of other brutal crimes—rapes, robberies, a kidnapping—but it was that first murder that landed him on death row.

Name: JUAN EDWARD CASTILLO
story:
Juan Castillo was convicted of killing 19-year-old rapper Tommy Garcia, Jr., in a December 2003 robbery on a San Antonio lovers' lane. He was sentenced to death in 2005.
One night, early in December of 2003, Castillo and his girlfriend teamed up with another couple to plan a robbery, according to court records. Their target — Garcia — counted among the former lovers of Castillo’s girlfriend, Debra Espinosa.

Name: ERICK DANIEL DAVILA
story:
Erick Davila was sent to Texas's death row after being convicted in the 2008 killings of a 5-year-old girl and her mother in a drive-by shooting at a "Hannah Montana"-themed children's birthday party. 
Targeting a rival gang member, the Fort Worth, Texas, man opened fire on a group of 15 children eating cake and ice cream on the front porch of Village Creek Townhouses.

Name: ROSENDO RODRIGUEZ, III
story:
Rosendo Rodriguez was sentenced to death for the 2005 murder of a pregnant prostitute whose body was later found stuffed into a suitcase in a Lubbock, Texas, landfill.
Then a Marine reservist, Rodriguez was visiting the West Texas city for training when he picked up Summer Baldwin late on Sept. 11.

Name: JOHN DAVID BATTAGLIA
story:
John Battaglia was convicted of killing his two daughters, 9-year-old Mary Faith and 6-year-old Liberty, on May 2, 2001.
Evidence at trial indicated Battaglia had a long history of domestic violence, particularly against his former wives. On Christmas morning in 1999, he beat his estranged wife, Mary Jean Pearl, in front of their two daughters. Battaglia was placed on probation, and a subsequent divorce decree included a protective order and restrictions. Battaglia continued to abuse Pearl, leading her to initiate legal action that revoked his probation.

Name: WILLIAM EARL RAYFORD
story:
William Earl Rayford was sent to Texas' death row after he strangled his ex-girlfriend, Carol Hall, in 1999, when he was out on parole for the murder of his ex-wife 13 years earlier under similar circumstances.
In November 1999, a few months after Hall kicked him out of her house, Rayford slipped back in and started a fight. The argument woke up her 11-year-old son, who Rayford stabbed in the back when he came out of his bedroom. The terrified mother fled down the street, barefoot and in her nightclothes, according to court records. But Rayford ran after her and threw her over his shoulder then headed for a creek. The wounded boy ran to a neighbor’s and called for police.

Name: ANTHONY SHORE
story:
Houston’s “Tourniquet Killer,” Anthony Allen Shore, admitted to raping and killing a string of Hispanic women over the course of nearly a decade. He was sentenced to death in 2004.
Shore’s arrest came eight years after his last known murder, the 1995 slaying of 16-year-old Dana Sanchez. He also killed 9-year-old Diana Rebollar and 14-year-old Laurie Tremblay, but it was the 1992 rape and murder of 21-year-old Maria del Carmen Estrada that netted the former wrecker driver a death sentence.

Name: RUBEN RAMIREZ CARDENAS
story:
When Hidalgo County, Texas, investigators first collared Mexican national Ruben Cardenas Ramirez for the rape and murder of his 15-year-old cousin, it didn’t immediately prompt any response from Mexico.
But 20 years later, disputes over alleged treaty violations in the early days of the investigation have become one of the hallmarks of the fraught case against the Guanajuato native convicted of kidnapping and killing Mayra Laguna.

Name: ROBERT LYNN PRUETT
story:
While serving a 99-year sentence for a murder in Harris County, Texas, Robert Lynn Pruett fatally stabbed Correctional Officer Daniel Nagle at the McConnell Unit in Beeville, Texas.
The incident began when a correctional officer took Pruett to get new shoes, causing him to miss the distribution of lunches. Instead of his normal meal, Pruett was given a sack lunch, which he took to the prison recreation area, in violation of unit rules. Nagle told Pruett he would have to eat his lunch before entering the recreation area and wrote up a disciplinary complaint.

Name: TAICHIN PREYOR
story:
On the evening of Feb. 26, 2004, Tai Chin "Box" Preyor fatally slashed and stabbed 20-year-old Jami Tackett after forcing his way into her San Antonio, Texas, home.
According to court documents, Preyor routinely purchased drugs from Tackett, which he then resold. Jason Garcia, who was present at the time of the 4 a.m. break-in, testified that he heard someone banging on the apartment door, then saw Preyor, attired in black hooded clothing and wearing gloves, peeping into the bedroom. Garza said Preyor stabbed him and then attacked Tackett, severing the woman's trachea, jugular vein and carotid artery. Garcia said he fled the apartment to summon help from neighbors. Tackett died before emergency medical personnel arrived. After the attack, Preyor fled the apartment, but retured moments later, apparently to search unsuccessfullly for his car keys. The keys were later found in the apartment.

Name: JAMES EUGENE BIGBY
story:
James Bigby, an auto mechanic from the small north Texas town of Kennedale, was sentenced to death for the 1987 murder of Michael Trekell, (by gunshot) and his infant son Jayson Kehler (by drowning). He was also accused, but not convicted, of shooting and killing two friends, Calvin Crane and Frank Johnson. At his 1991 trial, prosecutors argued that Bigby was driven by a belief that Trekell, Crane, and Johnson were conspiring to undermine a workers compensation claim he was bringing against Frito-Lay, where all four had at one time been employed.
Bigby’s lawyers presented an insanity defense, arguing that he suffered from paranoid schizophrenia. They enlisted Dr. James Grigson, a psychiatrist famously nicknamed “Dr. Death” for his prosecution-friendly testimony about the dangerousness of defendants. This case was an exception. Grigson told the jury that Bigby “was suffering from [this] serious, severe mental illness and was not aware of the difference between right and wrong." Another doctor’s report stated that Bigby believed “that private investigators from Frito-Lay are trying to kill him.”

Name: ROLANDO RUIZ, JR.
story:
In July 1992, Mark Rodriguez approached Rolando Ruiz, asking if he would be willing to murder his brother's wife, Theresa Rodriguez, in exchange for $2,000. 
Ruiz agreed and plans were made to fatally shoot the woman at a San Antonio restaurant. When Ruiz arrived at the scene, however, he saw a security guard and backed out. The murder was then rescheduled for a few days later at a San Antonio movie theater, but Michael and Theresa Rodriguez failed to appear. The murder was then rescheduled at the same theater. On this occasion, Ruiz saw Mark Rodriguez and Michael and Theresa Rodriguez enter their car at the theater's garage, and followed them to the Rodriguez home.

Name: TERRY DARNELL EDWARDS
story:
Terry Edwards was convicted of the July 18, 2002 shooting death of Mickell Goodwin, 26, a mother of two, during the robbery of a Subway sandwich shop in the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs.
The robbery occurred as Goodwin and store manager Tommy Walker, 34, who also was killed, opened the deli for business. Both victims were shot in the upper abdomen, and about $3,000 was taken in the robbery. Edwards, who previously had served prison time for a drug offense and theft, had been fired from the sandwich shop about a month before the robbery. He was arrested as he attempted to dispose of a pistol in a trash bin across the street from the business. His accomplice, Kirk Edwards, a cousin, surrendered the next day. He was later convicted of aggravated robbery and sentenced to 25 years in prison.

Name: CHRISTOPHER WILKINS
story:
Christopher Wilkins was convicted of fatally shooting Willie Freeman, a homeless Fort Worth man, and Mike Silva, who lived in Tarrant County, on Oct. 27, 2005.
Wilkins told authorities that in October 2005, he left a Houston halfway house, stole a truck and drove to Fort Worth. Once there, he encountered Freeman, who offered to sell him drugs. Wilkins paid $20 for what he thought was crack cocaine, but proved to be only a rock. Freeman and his supplier laughed at Wilkins. In ensuing weeks, Wilkins and Freeman used drugs together; Freeman apologized for the scam and gave Wilkins free drugs. On Oct. 27, Wilkins told Freeman he had drugs and guns stashed in west Fort Worth, and asked that the homeless man and his friend, Silva, help retrieve them. Sitting in the back of Silva's vehicle, Wilkins directed the men to an isolated area. He then shot Freeman in the back of the head. Silva tried to flee, but became entangled in the seat belt. Wilkins then shot Silva once in the neck and twice in the head.

Name: BARNEY RONALD FULLER, JR.
story:
Barney Fuller liked to fire guns, a hobby that led to repeated complaints from neighbors near the East Texas town of Lovelady. One dispute arose between Fuller and his neighbors, Nathan and Annette Copeland, who claimed he had damaged an electrical transformer with gunshots. On New Year's Day in 2003, Fuller telephoned Mrs. Copeland this greeting: "Happy New Year! I'm going to kill you." The Copelands lodged a complaint about the threat with the police.
When Copeland learned on May 13, 2003 that he had been charged with making a terroristic threat, he began drinking heavily, then marched to the Copeland residence early the next morning and fired about 60 rounds at the house with his AR-15 rifle. He then entered the residence, firing more shots with a pistol. Nathan Copeland was shot four times, three of the wounds inflicted from a distance of less than three feet. Annette took refuge in a bathroom, from which she called 9-1-1. The emergency operator heard a man's voice say, "Party's over, bitch," then a popping sound and silence. Annette was shot three times in the head. Fuller then targeted the couple's 15-year-old son, Cody, shooting him twice in the shoulder. He also looked for the couple's daughter, Courtney, 13, but could not find her in the darkness.

Name: PABLO LUCIO VASQUEZ
story:
An anonymous tip to police in the South Texas town of Donna in April 1998 reported that a 12-year-old boy, David Cardenas, had been murdered while attending a local party. The boy's scalped and mutiliated body, missing an arm, was found beneath sheets of aluminum in a nearby field.
A police investigation led to Pablo Vasquez and a 15-year-old accomplice, Andy Chapa. In a confession to police, Vasquez said he beat the boy over the head with a metal pipe, then tried to sever his head by hitting him in the face with a shovel.

Name: ADAM KELLY WARD
story:
Adam Ward was convicted for the June 13, 2005 murder of Michael "Pee Wee" Walker, a city of Commerce, Texas, code enforcement officer.
Ward was in his driveway washing his car when Walker parked in the street. As the officer walked the perimeter of Ward's property, taking photographs of possible code violations, the two men began quarreling. Ward went into his house and ran out with a .45-caliber semi-automatic pistol. As Walker tried to escape, Ward shot him as many as nine times. To obtain a capital decision in the case, prosecutors successfully argued that Ward interferred with Walker as he attempted to perform his official duties.

Name: COY WAYNE WESBROOK
story:
Coy Wesbrook was convicted of murdering his second ex-wife, Gloria Coons, and Antonio Cruz on Nov. 13, 1997 at the woman's Channelview, Texas, apartment.
According to trial testimony, Wesbrook and Coons married in 1995 and divorced the following year, although the couple occasionally lived together. Wesbrook moved out of their shared apartment in the summer of 1997, but on November 12 of that year, he had lunch with Coons, and she expressed interest in possible reconciliation.

Name: GUSTAVO JULIAN GARCIA
story:
Gustavo Garcia was convicted of the shotgun killing of Craig Turski, 43, an employee of a Plano liquor store on Dec. 9, 1990.
Trial testimony indicated Garcia entered the store with a .20 gauge sawed-off shotgun and demanded cash as his accomplice, Christsopher Vargas, carried beer to their car. Garcia shot Turski in the abdomen; when Turski fled the store, Garcia followed and shot him a second time.

Name: JAMES GARRETT FREEMAN
story:
James Freeman was convicted of fatally shooting Texas Game Warden Justin Hurst, 34, on March, 16, 2007, after a high-speed chase in Wharton County. The incident began after nightfall as another game warden staked out a rural area in which residents had complained of nocturnal gunshots.
About 11 p.m., a pickup truck slowly approached, and the officer heard a gunshot. (It is illegal to hunt from a roadway.) A chase reaching speeds of 130 mph, ensued, involving game wardens, sheriff's deputies, constables and Texas Department of Public Safety troopers. When the fleeing truck was disabled by spike strips placed on the roadway by officers, the driver pulled into a rural cemetery and fired at approaching officers, first with a handgun, then with an assault rifle. As officers exchanged gunfire with the man, Hurst left cover to obtain a clear shot. Witnesses saw Freeman aim his rifle at Hurst, and then the officer collapsed. He died of wounds to his arm and torso.

Name: RICHARD ALLEN MASTERSON
story:
Richard Allen Masterson was convicted of the Feb. 9, 2001 murder of Darin Honeycutt, whom he strangled in a choke hold and robbed of his car and personal items.
Masterson argued that the death occurred accidentally during sex. Masterson fled Texas after the killing and was apprehended in Florida, where he confessed to Houston police. In the punishment phase of his trial, Masterson's juvenile record was introduced as evidence, but little use was made of it by either side. (Masterson previously had served adult time in Texas and Georgia for burglary.)

Name: RAPHAEL DEON HOLIDAY
story:
Raphael Holiday was condemned for the Sept. 6, 2000 arson murders of three children, ages 7, 5 and 1.
Holiday had been accused by his wife, Tami Wilkerson, of sexually assaulting her 7-year-old daughter. Charges were filed and a protective order granted, but Holiday continued to contact Wilkerson, saying he wanted to visit their 1-year-old daughter, Justice. Wilkerson met with Holiday on several occasions in an attempt to control the escalating situation. About a week before the murders, Holiday telephoned Wilkerson, asking for help jump-starting his car. When she arrived, Holiday sexually assaulted her.

Name: LICHO ESCAMILLA
story:
Licho Escamilla fatally shot off-duty Dallas policeman Christopher James on the night of Nov. 25, 2002 after the officer ejected Escamilla and others from a northwest Dallas club following a disturbance.
As Escamilla fled a gunfight with police, he stepped over James, who had fallen to the ground, and shot him several times in the head at close range. He later admitted to killing James in a television interview.

Name: JUAN MARTIN GARCIA
story:
On the night of Sept. 17, 1998, Juan Garcia and three accomplices robbed Hugo Solano of $8 in the parking lot of a Houston apartment complex.
Garcia shot Solano, a 36-year-old former missionary, in the head and back with a .25-caliber handgun. The crime was one of several robberies and shootings committed by the group over a three-week period. Garcia was arrested when, during a traffic stop, the murder weapon was found in his possession, and he confessed the killing to police.

Name: DANIEL LOPEZ
story:
Shortly after midnight on March 11, 2009, Daniel Lopez ran past a Corpus Christi stop sign while traveling at almost 60 mph. When a policeman attempted to arrest him, Lopez threw punches at the officer, who responded with pepper spray. The officer fell to the ground when his Taser and radio wires wrapped around his legs. Lopez re-entered his car, and a chase involving multiple police units ensued.
Thinking he had an outstanding warrant for his arrest, Lopez fled, because he had drugs in his vehicle. As Lopez entered a freeway, officer Stuart Alexander placed "stop sticks" on the pavement. When Lopez approached the sticks, he veered toward the officer. Alexander attempted to avoid Lopez's vehicle, but was struck and killed.

Name: WILLIAM CHARLES MORVA
story:
William Morva was awaiting trial for an attempted armed robbery when he was taken to Montgomery Regional Hospital near Virginia Tech on Aug. 20, 2006 to be treated for a sprained ankle and wrist.
After using the bathroom, he assaulted and knocked out a sheriff’s deputy, seizing his gun. He then shot and killed hospital security guard Derrick McFarland.

Name: RICKY JAVON GRAY
story:
Ricky Javon Gray was convicted of the New Year's Day 2006 killing of 49-year-old Bryan Harvey, 39-year-old Kathryn Harvey and their daughters, 9-year-old Stella and 4-year-old Ruby.
The Harvey family was bound and beaten, their throats cut and the basement of their suburban Richmond, Va. home set on fire. Kathryn Harvey was co-owner of a local toy store, and Bryan Harvey was a well-known musician.

Name: ALFREDO PRIETO
story:
Alfredo Prieto was sentenced to death three times.
The first time was in California, in 1990, for the rape and murder of 15-year-old Yvette Woodruff in Ontario, near Los Angeles. Fifteen years later, while he was still on California's death row, Prieto's DNA was found to match crime scenes for four different murders in various parts of Virginia committed during the late 1980s (in total he has been linked to nine murders).
